svg.content: <mxfile host="www.draw.io" modified="2020-03-03T00:39:41.948Z" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.12; rv:73.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/73.0" etag="QwSnK0GGwhZTkLE2q9Z7" version="12.7.9" type="device"><diagram id="9GrYt10IR9ucB-TNQxC7" name="Page-1"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 78px; height: 1px; padding-top: 444px; margin-left: 181px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;

div.div: Function

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 408px; height: 1px; padding-top: 337px; margin-left: 576px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Based on the trajectory between these objects (which can be derived), it's possible to produce a certain range of output metadata.
This is a good example of an interface query (traversing the problem, filter, attribute, type, function, filter, & component interfaces) to generate a function that produces an output.
Given the output metadata, you can guess which objects were traversed, in which order, and which traversal steps have alternative options.
It's also possible to infer the set of possible positions & identities of the input.
For example, based on the contents of a recruiter's email, it's often possible to tell if:
- they had a particular series of conversations
- they evaluated you on a particular metric
- they spoke to a particular person
- they read one of your emails
- they looked at your social media
- they have a particular social circle/relationship type
- they were misinformed by one of their sources
- they were optimizing for a particular metric within a game
- they have been dealing with a particular problem
- they use a particular mental model
- they're operating with a particular system of understanding
- their cultural exposure (if they've seen a certain bit of media)
- their habits (if they practice telling jokes or being polite)
- they automated the email (are trying to minimize their work or transition into a coding role)
- they were paying attention
- they were following a protocol
- they have experience in the field or learned from someone who does

switch.text: Based on the trajectory between these objects (which can be derived)...

This function has an attribute update interface (A) and a rule update interface (R) which can be points of variance injection to the 3 dimensions

This function can shift the interim node operations so that the
third node is used as an input instead of the supported left & center nodes

switch.text: Given input & output, a set of internal functions/filters can be...

div.div: Type Causal Network

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 38px; height: 1px; padding-top: 771px; margin-left: 655px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;

div.div: Direct Causal Type
Relationship

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 29px; height: 1px; padding-top: 746px; margin-left: 146px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div: O

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 23px; height: 1px; padding-top: 936px; margin-left: 309px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: I

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 279px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1050px; margin-left: 451px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Based on the fact that you have the above type causal network and the direct causal type relationship, you know that these are the main ways to generate a rotated square shape.

Given the relationships allowed in this space, you can infer that the input is a triangle, especially if you know the number of operations allowed, or if you have interim metrics about the system state in between input & output.
Based on the fact that you know its rotatable, you could also infer the existence of a square type variable.

switch.text: Based on the fact that you have the above type...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 308px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 1126px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 168px; height: 1px; padding-top: 620px; margin-left: 1096px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; font-weight: bold; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div: Basis Vectors of System

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 695px; margin-left: 1289px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Given that you have four core vectors, you can infer that the object in question (the containing system) is 3-dimensional and has an extra rotation operation in addition to the 3 shifting operations.

Given that this extra rotation operation is included, you could infer that it's likelier to be a circle based on the fact that the rotation operation could be used to move the shape or to generate the shape, which is not known given just the function set.

switch.text: Given that you have four core vectors, you can...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 276px; height: 1px; padding-top: 903px; margin-left: 1289px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: The circle & ellipses are the likeliest systems, with the circle being slightly likelier because the function required to generate the ellipses requires combining a shifting & rotating operation (shifting the rotation operation) so given the extra effort required, it's not as likely.
Then the square shape has another layer of difference separating the system classes, so that's another layer of difference away in the probability distribution of output systems.

switch.text: The circle & ellipses are the likeliest system...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 228px; height: 1px; padding-top: 802px; margin-left: 1066px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; font-weight: bold; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div: Output System Probability Distribution

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 308px; height: 1px; padding-top: 463px; margin-left: 1946px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 358px; height: 1px; padding-top: 845px; margin-left: 2086px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Given a function (or the shape it generates, like a square), you can derive much of its metadata using its symmetries, repetitions, limits, & intersections.

div.b: sub-objects, generative objects, and generated objects

div.div: For example, if you didn't already know the corner object, you could derive it as the intersection of two lines connected at their endpoints, where the lines are part of an object having a closed circuit, so the corner represents a concave segment that can act as a limit on anything inside the shape if the shape is implemented as a container.
If you didn't already know the line object, you could derive it by identifying repeated qualities or splitting the object at clear divergence points.

If you didn't already know the diagonal object, you could derive it with the symmetry present by connecting two opposing corners, which represents a special kind of connecting line that connects two objects (corners) with opposing attributes values (corner position) and extra attributes (not connected), and divides the shape in half, which could be used as a shape generator.
Given these objects you've derived (corner & diagonal), other objects can be derived (triangle, center), since the diagonal forms a triangle and it traverses the center.
You can see how these could also be generated by intersections rather than using the symmetry route. The center object can be derived used the intersection of a line object and two opposing corners.
You could also generate the center object by an intersection of a subset of the symmetries.

You could generate the line midpoints & endpoints by the symmetries intersecting with the line objects, if you didn't already have a concept of a center or average function to apply to the line object.
By intersecting objects that don't normally overlap (like the midpoints of the lines), you can also generate other objects, like a circle that overlaps at the square's midpoints.

switch.text: Given a function (or the shape it generates, like a square),...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 238px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1150px; margin-left: 1756px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: How could you generate the metadata attribute that the square is symmetrical around its center on four structural symmetries, without knowing those symmetries?

If you knew the center or midpoint object, you could graph the distance from the center object, and noticing that it has a wave function, you could generate the implication that it's potentially symmetrical. Then you'd check that the wave had the same number of peaks as the shape had corners which are inherently equidistant in a square, or that the peaks were at equidistant intervals.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 358px; height: 1px; padding-top: 916px; margin-left: 2471px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: In order to generate the symmetries, you would need to generate a list of attributes that can be held fixed (like x or y position) and then transform the shape, keeping that attribute
fixed - if the shape retains its other attribute values once it's transformed, that transformation function & fixed attribute identifies a symmetry.

The attributes that are candidates include all dimensions of the space as well as metadata attributes embedded in the space, and the same for those of the adjacent objects. For example, a symmetry of a corner object is the line dividing its angle equally, which also produces a symmetry of the square object (the diagonal).

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 438px; height: 1px; padding-top: 926px; margin-left: 2871px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.b: Deriving core functions of a Function

div.div: In order to generate the core functions applicable to a function, you need to identify the primary dimensions of change & then combine those to generate the likely functions specific to that function.
For example, in euclidean space, the primary dimensions of change are along each dimension's value spectrum.
The core possible change is a shift in value (along one dimension).
Then by applying the core system function 'combine', you get a shift along two dimensions (vertically/horizontally).
Then next you would generate a chained operation (two shifts done consecutively).
Then with this chain, the next shift operation you would change the direction, and that would identify the direction attribute.
It would also imply the existence of an alternative path to get from the starting point to the current point, which is a straight line.

Then given the difference between the two lines (one with three chained lines and one a straight line), you would infer the existence of the 'smoothing' operation, which would smooth the angles and create a curve.

From this smoothing operation, you could generate the idea of a circle. With a wave function like the wave function of the distance from the boundary to the center of a square, you could connect two points on the line, flip the valleys so they're all peaks, then apply the smoothing operation on the resulting 8-peak object, which would generate a circle.
Now you have another route to the circle shape, given a square, in addition to the connection of the square's midpoints and smoothing the connecting lines.

To generate the core functions applicable to a square-generating function, you would iterate through these system & space operations, applying them to sets of the square's metadata & adjacent objects.

To generate the 'rotation' function, you could identify the corner object, isolate it, and try to generate a subset of the corner object that could be used to generate the corner object (the subset you need to generate a corner object a line length or two points, and an origin point, and an angle). Then you could find the operation necessary to generate the full corner object using this subset (rotate a second line, anchored at the corner point, at the angle). This is another way to generate the curve object if you didn't already have that generated.

switch.text: Deriving core functions of a Function...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 328px; height: 1px; padding-top: 660px; margin-left: 2487px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: There are subsets of metadata that are relevant for an object:
- interface generative metadata (determines attribute structure but not necessarily attribute values)
- generative (determining) metadata
- identifying metadata
- input/causative & output/emergent metadata
Within the set of generative metadata, there are many types that can be used to generate a function (symmetries, adjacent objects, limits, intersections).

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
